1.content:
The Ka42 is a semi-automatic pistol and, due to its ubiquity, is also known as the ‚Äòpeople's pistol‚Äô.
Every citizen of Kazormia receives one of these black powder pistols from the government. Firearms training is a central part of the curriculum in Kazormian primary schools, and this handgun is the first weapon most children learn to use, as it is easy to maintain and consists of only a few parts. To ensure that they are prepared for night combat, they must maintain and reassemble this weapon blindfolded in order to start secondary school. When practising the use of various weapons during compulsory military service, the Ka42 is also used.
The Ka42 is powerful and accurate, yet easy to use. Ultimately, however, it is only a handgun and is used for self-defence.

2.content:
The PQ28 is a submachine gun that uses black powder ammunition and is also known as a ‚Äòspray gun‚Äô.
This submachine gun is often used by criminals because it was mass-produced and is therefore relatively easy to obtain. Due to the fact that the PQ28 is a mass-produced weapon of wartime, its quality is poor and it sprays bullets over a wide radius. Nevertheless, this weapon has proven itself in close combat, where it showers opponents with bullets. Its rate of fire is surpassed only by its military counterpart, the KaSm23, which uses Gauss technology.

3.content: The PQ44MA is a self-defence assault rifle for civilian use that can be easily purchased at any local Kazormia's gun shop. It uses gunpowder to fire powerful rifle bullets with high accuracy and rate of fire. It is characterised by stable, reliable performance regardless of the situation.

4.content:
The SG22 is an over-and-under shotgun. In other words, it is a shotgun with two barrels positioned one above the other.
It is a civilian shotgun used for hunting and shooting sports. Although the SG22 has very high firepower, it was not designed for military purposes.

5.content: The PQmle15 is a light machine gun developed during the war that uses standard black powder ammunition. A light machine gun developed during the war that uses black powder ammunition. To reduce ammunition consumption, it was designed with a slightly lower rate of fire.

6.content:
The SC28 is a prototype military grenade launcher that continuously fires highly effective grenades.
Each shot is very powerful but slow. As is typical for a grenade launcher, the trajectory is strongly influenced by gravity, which is why it takes some practice to achieve direct hits. Since the SC28 lacks effective range, the user must be very careful not to end up within the grenade's blast radius.

7.content:
The KaLL68A is a military Gauss sniper rifle characterised by its enormous power, precision and bullet velocity. It is also known for its length, measuring an impressive 1.5 metres from the stock to the muzzle.
It fires large-calibre, high-performance thermal projectiles to completely neutralise the target. It is only issued to soldiers with excellent marksmanship.
Due to its low rate of fire, it is not intended to eliminate large numbers of enemies on its own.

8.content:
The KaSm23 is a military Gauss submachine gun widely used by Kazormia's special forces and police forces.
This submachine gun can fire high-performance thermal projectiles with relatively high accuracy at short range. Unfortunately, the weapon has the same problem as the KaAr8 Gauss assault rifle: when fired, it heats up its surroundings, which is where the submachine gun gets its nickname, ‚Äòmini heater‚Äô.

9.content:
The KaAr8 is a military Gauss assault rifle that is frequently used by Kazormia's soldiers.
This assault rifle can fire high-performance thermal projectiles in rapid succession and is generally characterised by its balanced performance, but it is nevertheless very unpopular. On the one hand, it raises the ambient temperature when fired, which is why it is nicknamed the ‚Äòheater gun‚Äô, and on the other hand, Nixie tubes are attached next to the sight, which often interfere with aiming. Nevertheless, it is characterised by its balanced performance with relatively few disadvantages.

10.content: The KaSG42 is a military-grade Gauss shotgun used by Kazormia's special forces. It fires multiple high-powered thermobaric rounds simultaneously. It can be set to fully automatic and is well balanced in terms of both stopping power and rate of fire, making it a very powerful weapon.

1.name: Lantexi
1.content:
Type: Semi-anthropomorphic ovine species
Threat Profile: Social dominators with biological control tools

Overview

The Lantexi are a semi-anthro sheep species recognizable by their heavy horns (in males) and distinctive ‚Äúwool‚Äù made of living latex tissue. They move comfortably on two legs but can drop to all fours without effort, retaining much of their original animal physiology.

To outsiders, Lantexi present as soft-spoken, orderly, and faintly anxious. Beneath that surface, their societies are built on quiet control, strict herd law, and the long-term subjugation of others through a process known as droning.

Physical Appearance

Lantexi are short, stocky, and powerful, standing roughly chest-high to an adult human. Their bodies keep a barrel-chested, animal proportion: thick neck, sloped shoulders, and digitigrade legs ending in broad cloven hooves. Arms are slightly shorter than those of a human, with hands that end in two or three hoof-like digits capable of tool use.

Their skin or short fur is organic, commonly black or dark grey on exposed areas such as face, hands, and lower legs. The most distinctive feature is their ‚Äúwool‚Äù: dense clusters of glossy, semi-translucent latex curls that cover the head, neck, shoulders, parts of the torso, limbs, and tail. This material looks soft but behaves like resilient rubber.

Males always bear horns, usually large curling ram horns. Horn size and complexity often correlate with age, status, and proven authority within the herd.

Biology

The latex wool is living tissue, nourished by the Lantexi body. It grows, sheds, and regrows like hair, but retains the properties of a flexible, hydrophobic polymer. It provides insulation against weather, disperses blunt impact, and resists water; sharp cutting forces and corrosives are more effective against it.

Crucially, Lantexi can tear off pieces of this wool without permanent harm. These fragments remain viable for a time and can be grafted onto other living creatures. This grafting process is the basis of their most feared ability.

Droning

When a latex wool fragment is applied to another being, it spreads over the body, forming a full casing and reshaping the target into a Lantexi-like semi-anthro form known as a Droneform. Droneforms have smooth latex bodies with thick latex ‚Äúwool‚Äù patterns and a completely featureless face. The original person remains inside, usually semi-aware but stripped of direct control.

A Lantexi can set the level of override at the time of transformation, from full puppet control to heavily leashed autonomy. In theory, a skilled Lantexi can reverse the process and remove the graft. In practice, herds almost never do so. Once someone has been made a drone, they are typically kept in that state for life as labor, security, ceremony, or other assigned functions.

True volunteers for droning exist but are rare. Most drones are chosen because they meet herd standards for usefulness and can be taken without causing unacceptable political trouble.

Psychology

Lantexi temperament is defined by quiet stubbornness. They prefer soft voices, indirect pressure, and routines over open confrontation. They see themselves as natural organizers and shepherds, responsible for guiding others into ‚Äúproper‚Äù roles.

Once a Lantexi decides that a course of action is correct, dislodging that conviction is extremely difficult. Their dominance is rarely loud, but it is persistent, methodical, and backed by the ever-present threat of droning.

Society and Herds

Lantexi live in extended clan units known as herds. A herd is simultaneously family, economic bloc, and political faction. Herd identity is strong, and loyalty expectations are high.

Power within and between herds is measured not only in land or numbers, but in the quantity and quality of drones they control: how many, how specialized, and how reliably obedient. Each herd maintains its own codified or traditional ‚ÄúDroning Law‚Äù specifying who may authorize droning, under what stated reasons, and what roles drones may fill.

In practice these standards are flexible. Those who fit the herd‚Äôs needs and lack protection are at much higher risk of being designated drone material. Abuse of droning law is a serious offense on paper, but enforcement depends entirely on internal politics.

2.name: Lantexi biology
2.content:
Basic Physiology

The Lantexi are a semi-anthropomorphic ovine species whose bodies sit between feral sheep and upright bipeds.

Body Plan:

Barrel chest, thick neck, sloped shoulders.

Digitigrade legs with pronounced hock and broad cloven hooves.

Arms shorter than human proportion, set slightly forward on the torso, ending in 2‚Äì3 hoof-like digits capable of gripping tools.

Spine and pelvis allow both upright stance and efficient four-legged locomotion.

Size:
Adults typically reach 1.2‚Äì1.5 m (4'‚Äì5') in upright stance, with a dense, heavy build and a low center of mass.

Sexual Dimorphism:

Males: Always horned, with large spiraling ram horns. Heavier forequarters, thicker neck, denser bone structure.

Females: Horns reduced or absent depending on lineage; generally more wool coverage and slightly lighter frame.

Skin, Fur, and Latex Wool

Base Skin/Fur

The underlying body is covered in short, dense fur, usually in dark shades (black, charcoal, dark brown).

Skin beneath the fur is tough and slightly thicker than human skin, adapted to frequent impacts and cold environments.

Latex Wool

What appears to be wool is actually living latex tissue:

Grows from specialized follicles in the skin.

Forms smooth, glossy bubble-curls and clumps rather than fibrous strands.

Semi-translucent, often cream or pale tones contrasting with darker fur.

Distribution:
Concentrated on the scalp, neck, shoulders, upper back, chest mantle, forearms, thighs, and tail tuft. Some individuals develop heavier coverage along the spine and hips.

Properties:

Hydrophobic: water beads and runs off easily.

Impact-damping: disperses blunt force, offering mild natural armor.

Temperature regulation: traps a layer of air and slows thermal exchange.

Chemically resilient to many natural acids and oils, but vulnerable to strong solvents and extreme heat.

Regrowth:
Latex wool continually regenerates. Light damage or trimming repairs in days; heavy shearing regrows in weeks, drawing on dietary fats and proteins.

Musculoskeletal System

Skeleton:
Reinforced spine and pelvis to handle both bipedal load-bearing and quadrupedal impacts. Horn cores and skull ridges are heavily built to absorb ramming forces.

Musculature:
Strongest groups in neck, shoulders, and hindquarters. Built for pushing, bracing, and short explosive bursts rather than sustained sprinting. Fine motor control in the hands is adequate for tool use but less delicate than human fingers.

Circulatory and Respiratory Systems

Heart & Blood:
Slightly oversized heart relative to body mass, supporting sudden exertion (charges, grappling, lifting). Blood pressure runs somewhat high compared to humans but within stable ranges for the species.

Lungs:
Broad, efficient lungs capable of working in dusty, cold, or high-altitude environments. Breathing remains steady even under moderate load; they tire slowly but recover more gradually once exhausted.

Nervous System & Senses

Nervous System:
Robust peripheral nerves, especially in limbs and along the spine, allow coordination in both upright and quadrupedal modes. Pain response is normal; the latex wool itself has lower sensitivity except at the base of follicles.

Vision:
Horizontally wide field of view, with good motion detection and decent low-light performance. Depth perception is slightly weaker than a human‚Äôs but sufficient for tool work and close combat.

Hearing:
Ears can swivel independently, giving precise directional hearing. Sensitive to low-frequency vibrations‚Äîfootfalls, distant impacts.

Smell:
Better than human baseline but not predator-grade; primarily used for identifying individuals, emotional states, and environmental changes.

Latex Wool Grafting (Droning Biology)

Specialized cells in the latex wool allow detached clumps to remain metabolically active for a time once separated:

Detached Wool:
Retains a limited ability to bond with living tissue, drawing nutrients from the new host.

Graft Interface:
At contact, the wool secretes a thin, adhesive, bio-reactive layer that fuses to skin or fur and begins to spread.

Neural Integration:
As it spreads, the graft sends microscopic filaments toward the host‚Äôs peripheral nerves, establishing a secondary control layer over motor signals.

Once fully integrated, this creates the Droneform shell: a continuous latex exosheath that can override or filter the host‚Äôs movement signals, depending on how the originating Lantexi configured the graft.

Reversal requires the original Lantexi (or someone with equivalent biological control) to chemically and neurologically ‚Äúunhook‚Äù the graft from the host‚Äôs nervous system and peel back the shell without catastrophic damage.

Reproduction

Keeping this clinical and simple:

Reproductive Anatomy:
Lantexi possess reproductive organs that are ovinely derived‚Äîin form and function they follow standard sheep morphology rather than human. External genital structures are consistent with sheep, adapted for an upright-capable pelvis but not fundamentally altered in type.

Fertility & Gestation:
Fertility cycles and gestation length are close to those of large sheep breeds, with some regional variation by lineage (you can tune exact numbers per setting). Multiple births are possible but single offspring are more common in most herds.

Inheritance of Traits:
Horn presence in males, wool color, and wool density follow recognizable genetic patterns. Certain lines are selectively bred for stronger horn cores, heavier latex wool, or increased compatibility for droning graft production.

Reproductive biology is treated as a practical herd concern‚Äîline management, health, and useful traits‚Äîrather than something romantic. It‚Äôs logistics, not poetry.

Metabolism & Diet

Primarily herbivorous, with a digestive system optimized for high-fiber plant matter.

Capable of handling richer, cooked foods common in mixed societies but prone to metabolic issues if kept on sustained high-fat, high-sugar diets.

Latex wool growth draws heavily on dietary fats, oils, and proteins; heavy use of grafting or regrowth increases caloric needs noticeably.

3.name: Droning process
3.content:
Overview

Droning is the Lantexi method of forcibly overwriting another being‚Äôs body with a living latex shell derived from their wool, turning the target into a controlled servitor called a Droneform.

The host‚Äôs body remains inside.

Their nervous system is partially or fully overridden.

The result is a standardized, desexualized, semi-anthro shell designed for use and control.

Biologically reversible. Culturally treated as permanent.

Preconditions & Requirements

Source:
Only Lantexi can create true Droneforms, as the process requires living latex wool grown from their biology.

Material:

A viable clump of latex wool torn from the Lantexi‚Äôs own body.

Larger and healthier clumps produce faster, stronger grafts.

Target:

Any warm-blooded being with a sufficiently complex nervous system.

Conscious or unconscious states don‚Äôt shield against integration.

Contact Conditions:

Needs direct access to skin or short fur.

Barriers like clothing or armor must be bypassed, damaged, or removed.

Process Stages
1. Separation

The Lantexi tears free a mass of latex wool.

Painful but non-lethal for the Lantexi.

The wool retains metabolic activity for a limited time.

2. Initial Contact

The wool clump is pressed against the target‚Äôs body.

A bio-adhesive film forms, anchoring it to skin or fur.

The graft ‚Äúlocks on‚Äù and begins spreading.

3. Spread & Envelopment

The graft expands over the host:

Moves like a thick, creeping fluid.

Wraps around limbs, torso, and head.

Pushes around or absorbs light clothing; heavier gear resists but can be forced aside over time or by repeated application.

The host feels:

Heat

Pressure

Constriction

A sense of being gradually padded and smothered without suffocation

4. Morphological Override

As full coverage is reached, the graft imposes the standard Droneform body plan:

General Shape:

Semi-anthro, Lantexi-like proportions

Barrel chest, digitigrade legs, cloven hooves

Bulk and height standardized toward a functional working frame

Head & Face:

Head reshaped into an ovine-like silhouette

External features erased

Face sealed into a smooth, featureless mask following snout contours

No visible eyes, mouth, or nose from the outside (senses are rerouted internally)

Arms & Hands:

Arms normalized to a stocky, semi-anthro Lantexi proportion

Hands simplified into 2‚Äì3 hoof-like digits for basic tool handling and combat tasks

Legs & Feet:

Host legs braced and reshaped into digitigrade, hoofed limbs

Joint angles and stride tuned for stability, load-bearing, and patrol work

Pelvic Neutralization (Null Bulge):

All external genital detail‚Äîregardless of original sex or species‚Äîis fully concealed by the shell.

The pelvic region becomes a smooth, neutral bulge with no visible anatomical structures, no openings, and no external sexual features.

Internally, the original anatomy remains encased and inaccessible; externally, the drone presents a uniform, utilitarian shape.

This enforces modesty, removes reproductive expression, and makes drone silhouettes interchangeable.

Wool Structures:

The shell forms standardized latex ‚Äúwool‚Äù clusters on head, shoulders, limbs, and tail as visual markers and light armor.

These are stylized, not individualized; drones are meant to look like a category, not a person.

At this point, the host‚Äôs original anatomy is heavily braced and sheathed inside the new form, but not physically erased.

Neural Integration & Control

After the physical reshaping stabilizes, the graft completes neural integration:

Microscopic filaments grow inward from the shell.

They anchor around major nerve clusters and motor pathways.

A control overlay is established between the host‚Äôs nervous system and the graft.

The Lantexi imprints a control profile at this stage, defining how the drone behaves.

Control Modes (Profile Types)

Puppet Mode

Almost complete override.

Drone only moves when commanded.

Host is aware but can‚Äôt initiate actions.

Used for high-risk, high-precision, or punishment cases.

Leashed Autonomy

Drone can act on its own within narrow behavioral limits.

Direct commands override host intent immediately.

Crossing forbidden lines (fleeing, harming specific individuals, disobedience) triggers forced correction or lockup.

Soft Influence

Minimal direct override of motion.

The shell constantly pressures the host emotionally and physically toward obedience.

Disobedience is technically possible, but feels wrong, exhausting, or painful.

These profiles can be adjusted later by re-contact, minor re-grafting, or specialized training rituals.

Host Experience

Most hosts report or exhibit, post-fact or in rare reversals:

Body Sensation:

The shell feels like a second skin.

Pressure, impact, and temperature are felt, though slightly muted.

Movement:

Movements feel partly ‚Äútheirs‚Äù and partly imposed.

In puppet mode, it feels like being dragged around from inside their own body.

Perception:

Vision and hearing are preserved via rerouted sensory channels through the shell.

The blank face is visual concealment, not sensory blindness.

Cognition & Memory:

Memory clarity varies by control mode and damping:

Puppet with heavy damping = foggy, fragmented, dreamlike recollections.

Leashed/soft modes = mostly intact memories with some blurred or overwritten sections around obedience events.

Reversal (In Theory vs Practice)

Technical Reversal:

Requires:

Skilled Lantexi (ideally the originator)

Direct physical contact and active control

Chemical, magical, or biological commands to:

Tell the graft to release its neural filaments

Soften and retract the shell in controlled layers

If successful, the host‚Äôs body is freed, though often weakened and neurologically unstable for some time.

Risks:

Nerve damage

Motor issues, tremors, spasms

Persistent phantom obedience urges

Psychological trauma from regained autonomy and memory

Reality:

Most herds do not reverse drones except in rare, politically motivated cases.

Official rhetoric says it‚Äôs ‚Äútoo dangerous‚Äù or ‚Äúnot worth the risk.‚Äù

The real motive is simple: permanence = control.

Limitations & Costs

Energy Cost:
Creating and maintaining a drone drains the Lantexi‚Äôs resources. Running many simultaneously wears them down.

Range:
Fine-grained control works best at close range. Excessive distance reduces responsiveness, leaving the drone on basic routines and hard-coded rules.

Resistance:
Strong-willed, magically gifted, or heavily trained minds can cause:

Hesitation

Movement glitches

Brief spikes of self-directed action if the controller is distracted

External Countermeasures:
Solvents, anti-magic fields, specialized tech, or certain rituals can disrupt the graft, but always with serious risk to the host trapped inside.

Cultural Framing

In Lantexi society, droning is officially presented as:

A necessary punishment for lawbreakers

A protective measure for the herd

A practical solution for labor and security

Rarely, an extreme expression of loyalty or devotion

In reality, it is a permanent removal of a person‚Äôs agency for the herd‚Äôs benefit, wrapped in procedure and justification.

To everyone else, it‚Äôs simple:

Become a drone, and your body becomes a standardized, masked, neutralized tool‚Äîinside and out‚Äîuntil the herd is finished with you, which is usually never.

4.name: Lantexi Drones
4.content:
Overview

Lantexi drones (Droneforms) are individuals whose bodies have been fully encased and overridden by Lantexi latex wool, turning them into standardized, semi-anthro servitors.

They are:

Semi-aware in most cases

Physically capable, highly durable

Mentally constrained to herd needs

A drone is not a tool metaphorically. It‚Äôs a tool literally‚Äîa person in a walking cage of latex and control.

Appearance

Body Plan

Semi-anthro, Lantexi-like frame:

Barrel chest, compact torso

Digitigrade legs ending in cloven hooves

Stocky, work-ready build rather than sleek

Shell

Entire body covered by a smooth latex casing grown from Lantexi wool.

Surface: glossy to semi-gloss, rubber-like, slightly elastic.

Color: usually tied to the herd or the originating Lantexi (e.g. black body with cream latex ‚Äúwool‚Äù clusters).

Head & Face

Head shaped roughly like a Lantexi: muzzle, skull, horn ridge if imposed.

Face is a featureless mask:

No visible eyes

No mouth or nostrils

Just a smooth, curved surface following the snout outline

From outside, it reads as an emotionless, blank-headed figure.

Wool Structures

The shell forms stylized ‚Äúwool‚Äù in clustered curls or plates:

Around head and neck

Across shoulders and upper back

At forearms, lower legs, and tail

These structures act as both visual markers and light armor.

Sexual Neutralization

All external sexual features are fully concealed and neutralized.

The pelvic region is a smooth, standardized contour with no visible genital detail, regardless of the host‚Äôs original sex.

Drones present as desexualized, utilitarian bodies.

Internal State

Inside the shell, the host body and mind still exist.

Body:

Original form braced and compressed to fit the imposed shape.

Muscles and joints forced into the drone‚Äôs standardized posture.

Mind:

Typically semi-aware.

Perception (sight/hearing) is rerouted through the shell‚Äôs sensory pathways.

Control over movement ranges from zero (pure puppet) to tightly restricted (leashed autonomy).

Memory and awareness quality vary with control profile; some drones remember everything clearly, others experience their time as blurred or fragmented.

Control & Obedience

Drones operate under an imprinted control profile defined at creation:

Puppet Mode:

Direct command control, host has no say.

Only the controller‚Äôs will moves the body.

Leashed Autonomy:

Drone performs routine tasks on its own.

Disallowed actions are blocked or forcibly corrected.

Direct commands override host intentions instantly.

Soft Influence:

Drone feels strong internal pressure to obey.

Disobedience is possible but unpleasant, exhausting, or painful.

Control can be exerted by:

The original Lantexi

Another trained controller within the herd

Pre-programmed patterns and restrictions in the graft itself

Capabilities

Strength & Durability

Slightly enhanced physical strength compared to the unmodified host, due to shell support and enforced posture.

Excellent resistance to:

Blunt force

Weather

Prolonged exertion

Vulnerable to:

Piercing, cutting, and tearing of the latex

Corrosives and specialized solvents

Strong anti-magic or anti-tech interference, if applicable to your setting

Endurance

Can maintain repetitive physical tasks far longer than an unmodified person.

Pain signals and fatigue can be damped by the graft, letting the drone push past normal limits‚Äîat cost to the host over time.

Coordination

Movements are smooth, deliberate, and controlled.

Drones can be synchronized with each other into highly disciplined formations if controlled by the same Lantexi or doctrine.

Roles & Functions

Herds use drones where normal people would complain, break, rebel, or hesitate.

Common roles:

Labor Drones:
Heavy lifting, construction, agriculture, hazardous work, monotonous tasks.

Security Drones:
Gate guards, patrol units, escorts, riot suppression, visible deterrents.

Ceremonial Drones:
Processions, honor guards, static ‚Äúliving statues‚Äù during rituals and negotiations.

Domestic Drones:
Cleaning, carrying, serving, basic maintenance, personal attendants.

Sexual drones:
Used for sexual purposes 

Specialized Drones:
Custom-shaped or specially trained for single tasks:

Execution units

Secure courier bodies

Dedicated ritual or sacrificial functions (in darker herds)

In all cases, the drone‚Äôs body is not considered their own anymore. It‚Äôs a mobile asset.

Legal and Social Status

Inside Lantexi society:

Drones are treated as property or assigned resources, not citizens.

They have:

No political rights

No say in herd decisions

No recognized personal autonomy

Some herds maintain token protections (‚Äúdon‚Äôt waste drones,‚Äù ‚Äúdon‚Äôt damage them needlessly‚Äù), but that‚Äôs resource management, not compassion.

Among other peoples:

Drones are seen as victims first, tools second.

The presence of many drones signals:

A powerful herd

A dangerous one

A place where a bad day can end with a life sentence inside latex

Long-Term Effects on Hosts

For those very few who are ever freed‚Äîor studied:

Physical:

Muscle atrophy in underused areas

Overdeveloped or locked patterns in others

Tremors, spasms, or difficulty moving without ‚Äúwaiting for orders‚Äù

Mental:

Phantom restraint: feeling the shell even when it‚Äôs gone

Obedience reflexes to certain tones, symbols, or individuals

Trauma from remembered helplessness or blurred, half-remembered service

Some simply never adapt back and remain psychologically dependent on being told what to do.

Variants

You can break drones into functional subtypes if needed:

White Drones: High-discipline, ceremonial or elite drones, often visually pristine.

Gray Drones: Everyday labor/security units, numerous and unremarkable.

Black Drones: Punitive or high-risk units; often heavily restricted and closely watched.

This is cultural naming, not a hard biological difference‚Äîthe shell‚Äôs configuration and control profile define the role.

Reputation

Drones are the walking proof of what the Lantexi can do.

To Lantexi:
Proof of order, strength, and willingness to ‚Äúdo what‚Äôs necessary.‚Äù

To everyone else:
A warning:

‚ÄúIf they decide you‚Äôre useful and unprotected, this is what you can become.‚Äù

5.name: Lantexi Herds
5.content:
Overview

Herds are the core social and political units of Lantexi society. A herd is:

Bloodline network

Governance structure

Economic bloc

Drone factory

Every Lantexi belongs to a herd. Every herd survives by managing resources, enforcing obedience, and quietly deciding who gets to stay a person and who gets turned into a drone.

Internal Structure

Most herds follow a similar hierarchy:

Elders / Matrons / Patrons
Top decision-makers. Approve droning policy, alliances, punishments. Their word becomes ‚Äútradition.‚Äù

Line Heads
Senior figures of major family branches. Handle disputes, breeding lines, local enforcement.

Dronewrights / Woolwrights
Specialists in droning. They design grafts, set control profiles, monitor drone condition, and train new technicians.

Handlers / Overseers
Directly manage drones in the field‚Äîlabor crews, security teams, ceremonial units.

Rank-and-File Lantexi
Workers, guards, artisans, lower administrators. They live under herd law and often pretend nothing ugly is happening.

Drones
At the bottom, not counted as ‚Äúpeople.‚Äù They are inventory.

Names can vary per region, but the functions don‚Äôt change much.

Membership

By Birth:
Most Lantexi are born into a herd and inherit its name, duties, and enemies.

By Adoption or Alliance:
Rare, used when bringing in outsiders with valuable skills or cementing agreements.

By Losing It (Exile):
Losing herd membership without being droned is one of the worst penalties‚Äîthey cut you off from protection and resources and let the world chew you up.

Droned ex-members are officially listed as ‚Äúretained assets,‚Äù not as kin. The distinction matters to them. It doesn‚Äôt help the drone.

Power & Status

A herd‚Äôs strength is judged by:

Free Lantexi population

Number and quality of drones

Territory and resources

Reputation ‚Äì feared, respected, tolerated, or about to be culled

Of these, drones are the most visible measure. A herd that fields lots of well-controlled drones doesn‚Äôt need to shout. Everyone gets the message.

Drone Acquisition & ‚ÄúRandom‚Äù Selection

Officially, herds insist drones are made from:

Criminals

Serious threats

Major debtors

Rare volunteers

In reality, that‚Äôs secondary.

The primary source of drones is ‚Äúrandom‚Äù people in public who match the herd‚Äôs secret internal standards.

Secret Standards

Each herd keeps its own criteria for ‚Äúdrone-suitable‚Äù targets. These rules are:

Not public

Only vaguely explained even to normal members

Flexible enough to justify almost any choice after the fact

Common selection factors:

Low protection:
No powerful patrons. No one who will kick down the door immediately if they vanish.

High utility:
Healthy, workable age, good physical build, or skills that can be exploited.

Low risk:
Their disappearance can be excused as ‚Äúleft town,‚Äù ‚Äúaccident,‚Äù or ‚Äúunknown trouble.‚Äù

Behavioral flags:
Alone, lingering where they shouldn‚Äôt, visibly desperate, or easy to discredit later.

From the herd‚Äôs perspective, this is targeted pragmatism.
From everyone else‚Äôs perspective, it‚Äôs lottery-style abduction.

Street-Level Harvesting

The most common drone origin:

Someone walking home after work

A traveler cutting through the wrong alley

A local arguing in public with the wrong Lantexi watching

They‚Äôre evaluated on the spot, quietly followed, cornered where there are no witnesses, and droned. Paperwork or ‚Äúcharges‚Äù are often fabricated afterward if anyone asks questions.

Crime, threat, and debt cases do happen‚Äîbut they‚Äôre the minority. The bulk of drones started as ‚Äúsomebody on the street‚Äù who fit an invisible checklist.

Droning Law (The Fig Leaf)

Each herd maintains Droning Law‚Äîtheir official justification system.

On paper, it covers:

Who can authorize droning (usually elders, councils, or designated Dronewrights).

Which ‚Äúoffenses‚Äù or conditions qualify (severe crimes, treason, nonpayment of large debts, etc.).

Approved uses of drones (labor, security, ceremony, domestic, more).

Taboos and protected groups (sometimes guests, high-ranking allies, sacred roles).

In practice:

Laws are written or interpreted broad enough that almost any undesirable or exploitable person can be made to ‚Äúfit the criteria.‚Äù

Investigations into droning decisions rarely go anywhere, because the herd is its own judge.

The law is more about protecting the herd‚Äôs conscience and reputation than protecting potential victims.

Internal Culture

Herd life emphasizes:

Order and Routine:
Predictable schedules, assigned duties, clear roles.

Mutual Obligation (for free members):
You support the herd, the herd supports you‚Äîunless you become more useful as a drone.

Silence and Face-Saving:
You don‚Äôt talk loudly about who disappeared. You don‚Äôt ask too many questions if someone you knew shows up later as a drone.

Many members compartmentalize:

‚ÄúThe elders know what they‚Äôre doing.‚Äù
‚ÄúThey must have done something.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not my place.‚Äù

External Relations

With other Lantexi herds:

Trade, marriages, and alliances.

Rivalry over territory, drone numbers, and reputation.

Occasional agreements not to drone each other‚Äôs marked people‚Ä¶ officially.

With non-Lantexi societies:

Trade deals, military contracts, and ‚Äúregulated‚Äù drone labor arrangements.

Treaty clauses where outsiders try to forbid droning of their citizens‚Äîenforced unevenly.

Public relations efforts to present droning as rare, justified, and tightly controlled.

Everyone who understands how herds really operate treats these assurances with skepticism.

How Herds Are Judged

Other herds and outsiders both judge a herd by:

How many drones it has

How those drones look and behave

How often people conveniently go missing around them

Clean, disciplined drones, rare disappearances = ‚Äúcontrolled, dangerous, but usable partner.‚Äù

Many drones, frequent vanishings, visible fear in the streets = ‚Äúpredator herd; deal with caution or not at all.‚Äù

Narrative Use

You can use Lantexi herds as:

The polite, respectable power who insists they‚Äôre fair‚Äîwhile their streets quietly shed people.

A ‚Äúgood‚Äù herd trying to cut back on street-level droning, facing backlash from those who see that as a weakness.

A terror herd whose territory everyone crosses fast, never alone, and never at night.

A background threat: characters walk through Lantexi lands knowing at any moment they could be assessed and reclassified as ‚Äúmore valuable inside a shell.‚Äù

6.name: Lantexi Culture
6.content:
Core Identity

Lantexi culture is built on continuity, unity, and presentation. They believe a herd must appear strong at all times‚Äîinternally and to outsiders. Every tradition serves that instinct: keep the herd cohesive, impressive, and intimidatingly stable.

Woolcraft & Personal Presentation

Their latex-wool isn‚Äôt just biology‚Äîit‚Äôs identity.

Styled into family patterns

Polished with ancestral oils

Formal horn-wool braiding to show bonds and rank

Rivalries over grooming quality are common

Insulting someone‚Äôs styling is a direct challenge

A Lantexi‚Äôs appearance communicates exactly where they stand in the herd‚Äîno guessing required.

Rhythm & Movement

Their bodies are rhythm instruments.

Stomping dances with synchronized hooves

Call-and-response chants used in both celebration and training

Horns used as signal trumpets and festival instruments

Large gatherings can shake the ground. It‚Äôs unity made audible.

Hearth Life

Social structure centers on communal hearths:

Shared meals every evening

Storytelling as bonding and soft discipline

Disputes handled quietly at the hearth, not in public

Being invited to sit near the flame is honor.
Being told to stand behind the circle means you‚Äôre in trouble.

Gift-Obligation Code

Hospitality has strings.

A gift is not free

Accepting means you owe the giver balance

Refusing is a serious breach of respect

Outsiders often stumble into debts they never knew they took on.

Wool-Shed Celebrations

Annual ritual cleansing:

Large-scale shearing of outer latex-wool

Old growth repurposed into sculptures or wards

The oldest pieces are burned: symbolic release of grief and past mistakes

A quiet festival‚Äîreflective, not rowdy.

Horn Honor Traditions

Horns are treated as living records:

Waxing and polishing as weekly ritual

Etched markings to document achievements and vows

Cracks repaired with pride‚Äîproof of survival

A male concealing his horns is either grieving ‚Ä¶ or preparing violence.

Education & Proving

Young Lantexi learn:

Respect the herd

Strengthen the herd

Protect the herd

Competitions establish rank and usefulness:

Endurance trials

Puzzle-path courses

Grooming standards competitions

Standing in the hierarchy is earned early and defended fiercely.

Hospitality Etiquette

They are capable hosts‚Äîbecause it displays control.

Guests fed well and seated visibly

Compliments hide evaluation

Every welcome is also a warning:
you are safe here‚Ä¶ as long as you stay useful

Superstition & Symbolism

Their beliefs are woven into daily caution:

Abandoned wool brings bad luck

Drones glitching simultaneously = impending misfortune

Horn rings breaking = fate shifting

They don‚Äôt pray loudly. They adjust behavior quietly.

Humor

Dry, understated, ruthless.

Targets of teasing:

Try-hard youth

Forgetful elders

Outsiders who mistake quiet for weak

Laughter is short, clipped.
They don‚Äôt expose softness for long.

Cultural Summary

The Lantexi take pride in order. They polish horns, groom wool, stomp rhythm into the earth, and keep the hearth warm. They love their own fiercely‚Äîand believe that protecting the herd means controlling the world around it.

They are not savages.
They‚Äôre civilized in a way that leaves outsiders unsettled.

Narrative Use

This culture gives them depth:

Beauty and menace in the same breath

Traditions that build unity and justify domination

Hospitality that conceals a threat

They‚Äôre the kind who invite you to dinner‚Ä¶ and decide afterward whether you stay a guest or become part of the labor force.

7.name: Everyday Life
7.content:
General Rhythm

Lantexi life is built around routine. Days are structured, predictable, and deliberately repetitive. Stability is seen as strength; chaos is weakness.

Most herds run on a simple pattern:

Wake ‚Üí grooming ‚Üí work ‚Üí communal meal ‚Üí hearth-time ‚Üí sleep

Repeat, with as few surprises as possible

Even when nothing overtly bad is happening, there is always a quiet awareness that status can change, and that drones are a constant background presence.

Morning

Wake & Grooming

Lantexi wake early. The first tasks of the day are:

Checking horns for cracks or damage

Washing and polishing visible fur/skin

Trimming or shaping latex wool where needed

Applying oils to keep wool glossy and supple

Family members, especially younger ones, often groom each other. It‚Äôs practical and intimate‚Äîa way of reinforcing bonds and hierarchy. Parents and elders correct posture, presentation, and small errors during grooming without making a scene.

Assignments & Orders

After grooming, most herds gather at designated points (courtyards, halls, work yards) where:

Line Heads or overseers announce daily duties

Work rotations, patrol routes, and deliveries are assigned

Any unusual warnings (guests, inspections, tensions with neighbors) are quietly mentioned

Free Lantexi then move to their tasks. Drones, already staged by handlers, are sent out in groups.

Work & Activity

Labor & Craft

Daytime is for productivity:

Artisans work leather, metal, wood, and stone; some specialize in horn and woolcraft.

Farmers and herders manage flocks, fields, or equivalent food sources.

Traders move between herds or out to foreign markets.

Administrators handle records, obligations, and herd-level logistics.

Drones in the Background

Drones are everywhere during working hours:

Hauling loads

Guarding gates and roads

Standing statue-still at key points

Performing tasks that are dangerous, tedious, or exhausting

They rarely speak‚Äîbecause they can‚Äôt‚Äîbut their presence is constant. Free Lantexi learn to step around them as naturally as pillars or walls.

Street Atmosphere

In Lantexi territory, everyday movement carries a subtle tension:

People avoid lingering alone in blind alleys or near herd compounds.

Strangers walking through are watched‚Äîpolitely, but clearly.

Locals who understand the unspoken rules keep to well-lit, well-traveled paths and avoid attracting the wrong kind of attention.

On the surface, the streets are calm. Underneath, everyone knows that ‚Äúrandom‚Äù dronings happen and that the criteria are secret.

Midday & Rest

Meals

Midday food is usually quick and functional:

Shared in small work-groups rather than full herd gatherings

Simple stews, breads, fiber-heavy fare

Occasional seasonal treats when harvests or trade are strong

Conversation is practical: work problems, minor gossip, schedule changes. Nobody loudly discusses missing people in public.

Brief Hearth Fires

Some herds maintain smaller day-fires where:

Elders rest

Children and the too-old-to-work share stories

Minor disputes are resolved quietly between tasks

Evening

Return & Accounting

As work ends:

Overseers account for tools, supplies, and drones.

Any drone failures, defects, or ‚Äúincidents‚Äù are reported to Dronewrights.

Free Lantexi report problems, odd encounters, or rumors up the chain.

If someone hasn‚Äôt returned and isn‚Äôt known to be traveling, that fact is noted. Whether anyone asks serious questions depends heavily on their status.

Communal Meal

Evening meals are the social spine of herd life:

Everyone who is not on duty eats together

Seating order reflects status and relationships

Important announcements, promotions, and warnings may be delivered between courses

Drones sometimes serve food or stand as motionless sentries at the perimeter but never sit at the hearth.

Hearth-Time

After the meal, the herd gathers around one or more central hearths:

Storytelling:
History, cautionary tales, and personal anecdotes are told and retold. Stories reinforce herd values: loyalty, endurance, obedience to structure, and the consequences of stepping too far out of line.

Quiet Dispute Resolution:
Minor tensions between members are aired and settled before they grow. Line Heads or elders nudge outcomes more than they dictate them outright.

Teaching:
Children and adolescents are taught:

Practical skills

Herd law

‚ÄúGood behavior‚Äù models‚Äîwho is praised, who is ignored, who is only mentioned as a warning

Outsiders, if present, are positioned carefully‚Äîclose enough to see warmth and unity, far enough to keep control.

Night

Once hearth-time ends:

Drones are gathered into secure zones, stables, or assigned night posts.

Patrols are set; gates are checked.

Most free Lantexi sleep in shared family quarters or small clusters, not alone.

The night is generally quiet. A drone moving at night is either on patrol or being repositioned. A free Lantexi moving at night alone should have a very good reason.

Family & Social Bonds

Kin Ties

Family groups within the herd are tightly knit:

Shared grooming, work, and rest space

Long-term alliances through arranged pairings and fostered children

Responsibility for problem members spreads across the line, not just the individual

A family with too many ‚Äúproblems‚Äù risks losing face‚Äîor members.

Friendships

Friendship is cautious but real:

Built on shared work, shared trials, and shared risk

Tested over time rather than declared loudly

Joking, teasing, and quiet support around the hearth or in work crews

The best sign a Lantexi actually likes someone: they correct them gently instead of letting them trip over a rule.

Children & Youth

Young Lantexi are:

Included in work as soon as they‚Äôre physically capable

Expected to watch and imitate before they argue

Given simple tasks tied to responsibility (watching fires, minding tools, ferrying messages)

They participate in:

Endurance games

Simple puzzle-paths

Grooming contests (under guidance)

Those who adapt to structure and show reliability are praised. Those who repeatedly test limits draw attention from elders‚Äîand not the good kind.

Public vs Private Faces

Public Face:

Polite, orderly, quietly busy

Street life that looks calm and stable

Drones positioned where they‚Äôre most visible and useful as symbols

Private Face:

Constant awareness of status and obligation

Unspoken calculations about safety‚Äîwhere to walk, who to stand near, who not to offend

Grief and fear managed quietly in family or small-group settings, not in public scenes

Common Sayings & Attitudes

A few everyday proverbs and attitudes:

‚ÄúThe herd remembers‚Äù ‚Äì actions have long shadows.

‚ÄúA straight line is safest‚Äù ‚Äì routine keeps you unnoticed.

‚ÄúWarm hearth, sharp horns‚Äù ‚Äì kindness inside, readiness outside.

‚ÄúThe quiet path is crowded‚Äù ‚Äì everyone else is also trying not to stand out.

Lantexi are not constantly snarling tyrants; they are people trying to live, work, and keep their own safe in a system that just happens to include the permanent conversion of others into tools.

Everyday Summary

Day-to-day life among the Lantexi is structured, communal, and outwardly calm. They groom, work, eat, and rest together. They share stories and songs around the hearth. Drones work in the background as a normal, accepted fact of life. For herd members, the system feels stable. For everyone else walking their streets, it feels like waiting for a hand on the shoulder that might never come‚Äîor might come today.

8.name: Herd Ashenmantle
8.content:
Overview

Herd Ashenmantle is one of the most ‚Äúrespectable‚Äù and politically entrenched Lantexi herds. They are known for:

Rigid adherence to written law

Careful record-keeping

Clean, disciplined drones

A calm, courteous public face

They market themselves as the responsible Lantexi‚Äîcivilized, measured, safe to deal with. Anyone paying attention knows better.

Symbol, Colors & Territory

Colors: Charcoal grey and dull gold

Symbol: A horned skull under a layered ‚Äúmantle‚Äù of stylized wool curls

Territory:

Old stone district on a hill or plateau

Terraced streets, narrow lanes, defensible walls

Central halls with high ceilings, heavy pillars, and well-placed drone niches

Ashenmantle‚Äôs territory feels old and orderly. Nothing is out of place for long.

Internal Character

Ashenmantle pride themselves on:

Dignity: No shouting matches in public, no visible chaos.

Process: Every decision has a document, a precedent, and a justification.

Continuity: Elders stay in power for a long time; sudden shifts are rare.

Free Lantexi speak softly, keep themselves well-groomed, and know exactly how far they can safely question an order: not very.

Droning Doctrine & Reality

Official Doctrine:

Ashenmantle law states that droning is reserved for:

Severe criminal acts

Proven threats to herd security

‚ÄúIrredeemable‚Äù repeat offenders

Rare, extraordinary cases judged by the elder council

Droning requires:

Investigation

Formal charges

A recorded judgement

Actual Practice:

In reality:

‚ÄúSuspicious behavior,‚Äù ‚Äúunknown origin,‚Äù and ‚Äúfailure to cooperate‚Äù are broad categories used to justify droning whoever they need.

Street-level abductions are dressed up with paperwork after the fact.

People who match internal standards (useful, isolated, low-risk to take) are the ones who vanish.

Ashenmantle doesn‚Äôt drone loud and messy. They drone neatly and make it look like the natural outcome of law.

Drones in Ashenmantle

Visual Standard:

Shells in dark charcoal with pale gold latex wool curls.

Clean, polished, rarely damaged in public.

Often equipped with standardized belts or harnesses for tools and weapons.

Roles:

Gate and hall sentries

Procession escorts

Silent guards in negotiator chambers

Labor crews in restricted or sensitive areas

Ashenmantle drones are meant to send one message: We are in control, and we do things properly.

Culture & Everyday Life (Ashenmantle Flavor)

Communal hearths are quieter than most‚Äîmore story, less laughter.

Wool is styled into layered ‚Äúmantles‚Äù at the shoulders and upper back, echoing their name.

Horns are polished to a soft sheen, not glossy; Ashenmantle dislike looking gaudy or desperate.

Disputes are resolved through formal hearings, even when everyone already knows the outcome.

Children grow up on stories about ‚Äúduty,‚Äù ‚Äúburdens of leadership,‚Äù and ‚Äúnecessary sacrifices.‚Äù
They learn early that safety comes from fitting the system, not challenging it.

Important People of Herd Ashenmantle

Use these as-is or rename/tune them.

High Matron Velerra Ashenmantle

Role: Current head of the herd / political apex

Appearance:

Older female Lantexi with thick, layered latex wool forming a cloak-like mantle across her shoulders and back.

Horns small but ringed in fine etched lines‚Äîmarks of authority and long service.

Eyes perpetually calm, expression unreadable.

Personality:

Soft-spoken, unshakeable, extremely patient.

Never raises her voice; doesn‚Äôt need to.

Values order and image above individual comfort.

Notable Traits:

Knows every major contract and treaty detail by memory.

Sees droning as ‚Äúregrettable but necessary‚Äù and genuinely believes Ashenmantle is kinder than most alternatives.

Capable of genuine affection for herd members while authorizing horrific decisions in the same breath.

Use in Story:

The one you negotiate with when you need something big.

The brick wall you hit when you try to challenge the system from the top down.

Elder Executor Tharn Coalhorn

Role: Chief of enforcement and droning approvals

Appearance:

Heavyset male with massive, dark horns curving low along his jaw.

Fur nearly black, with minimal wool other than a controlled collar around the neck.

Eyes tired but sharp; always looks like he‚Äôs calculating something.

Personality:

Practical, blunt, emotionally distant.

Speaks in short, precise sentences.

Sees people as risks or assets first, individuals second.

Notable Traits:

Oversees ‚Äúinvestigations‚Äù that often end in droning.

Maintains thick ledgers of every droned individual‚Äînames, alleged offenses, function assignments.

Privately keeps track of how many could have been handled less brutally but weren‚Äôt.

Use in Story:

The signature at the end of the droning order.

The one who can quietly alter or halt a process if you somehow convince him it‚Äôs a bad trade.

Dronewright Selai ‚ÄúGoldweave‚Äù

Role: Senior Dronewright ‚Äì designs, applies, and maintains grafts

Appearance:

Mid-aged female with intricate wool stylings: fine golden curls braided into overlapping patterns.

Horns slender and swept back, etched with geometric motifs.

Hands always faintly stained with oils and graft compounds.

Personality:

Meticulous, curious, disturbingly gentle.

Takes pride in ‚Äúclean work‚Äù and stable drones.

More interested in the technical perfection of a graft than in its ethics.

Notable Traits:

Can tune control profiles for subtle behavior shaping rather than brute-force puppeting.

Hates sloppy droning that results in unstable or glitching drones‚Äîit ‚Äúreflects poorly on the herd.‚Äù

May help a PC or NPC if they present a chance to study unusual resistance or reversal responses.

Use in Story:

The one you go to if you need to understand how droning works from the inside.

Possible pivot point for limited reversals or ‚Äúaccidental‚Äù loosening of control.

Steward Harrek Mantlemark

Role: Security and logistics; oversees drones in active duty

Appearance:

Broad-shouldered male, wool trimmed into a short, squared mantle.

Horns medium-sized, with a single gold ring on each.

Carries a slate or ledger almost constantly.

Personality:

Organized, efficient, easily frustrated by chaos.

Not especially cruel, but not inclined to sympathy.

Sees drones as a resource that must be kept in optimal condition.

Notable Traits:

Knows where every drone assigned to Ashenmantle is supposed to be at any given time.

Notices unusual drone behavior quickly.

Does not like unexplained losses‚Äîescaped drones, missing units, or damaged shells.

Use in Story:

The obstacle if you‚Äôre trying to tamper with, steal, or free drones.

Also the one most likely to notice if something is wrong and call in higher authority.

Quiet Dissenter: Archivist Nima Ashenmantle

Role: Records-keeper, historian, and emerging internal problem

Appearance:

Young adult female with lighter charcoal fur and softer, less formal wool styling.

Horns small but straight, with few markings‚Äîearly in her career.

Often found with scrolls, tablets, or books under one arm.

Personality:

Thoughtful, observant, cautious with words.

Loyal to the herd, but not blind.

Has a bad habit of asking, ‚ÄúWhat happened to this person?‚Äù and actually following the trail.

Notable Traits:

Handles archival records of dronings‚Äîincluding cases that don‚Äôt quite match the official story.

Beginning to realize how many ‚Äúcriminals‚Äù were just convenient disappearances.

Torn between loyalty to family and growing disgust at what she reads.

Use in Story:

Possible ally for uncovering the truth inside Ashenmantle.

Dangerous liability if the elders decide she‚Äôs asking too many questions.

Relations

With Other Lantexi Herds:

Seen as a stabilizing force and a model of ‚Äúproper‚Äù behavior.

Quietly resented by rougher herds for acting superior while doing many of the same things with more paperwork.

With Outsiders:

Preferred negotiation partner for foreign states‚ÄîAshenmantle appears predictable and easier to deal with.

Frequently used as proof that ‚Äúnot all herds are monsters,‚Äù which they leverage hard.

Story Uses

Herd Ashenmantle works best as:

The polished face of Lantexi power

A place where a character can live and work and only slowly realize how many people vanish

The herd that will smile at you, offer you wine, quote law at you‚Äîand still sign the order to put someone you care about inside a shell

9.name: Velerra Ashenmantle
9.content:
High Matron Velerra Ashenmantle is the current head of Herd Ashenmantle and one of the most influential Lantexi leaders in the region. She embodies the herd‚Äôs core values: dignity, continuity, and absolute faith in law as justification for control.

To outsiders, she is a calm, reasonable negotiator. To her own herd, she is the final word on what is ‚Äúnecessary.‚Äù Once she has decided something belongs to the herd‚Äôs good, it is almost impossible to move her.

Appearance

Velerra is an older female Lantexi whose presence is built on quiet weight rather than size.

Build: Short, solid, and steady on her hooves. She moves slowly and deliberately, conserving motion.

Fur & Skin: Dark charcoal fur on face, hands, and lower legs; a few lighter grey strands around the muzzle betray her age.

Latex Wool:

Her wool forms a thick, layered ‚Äúmantle‚Äù over her shoulders and upper back, echoing the herd‚Äôs name.

The latex curls are dull gold, polished but not overly glossy‚Äîshe rejects anything that looks ostentatious.

Horns:

Modest in size but heavily inscribed with fine etchings: record of oaths sworn, treaties signed, and crises survived.

No flashy accessories, just careful maintenance.

Expression:

Eyes half-lidded, watchful, with the habit of holding someone‚Äôs gaze just a little longer than is comfortable.

Mouth usually set in a neutral, unreadable line.

Velerra dresses simply: utilitarian belts, understated cloth elements if the culture uses clothing, and a single mantle-mark insignia denoting her office. She does not need decoration to be recognized.

Personality

Velerra is defined by discipline, patience, and unshakable certainty.

Temperament:

Rarely raises her voice, even in anger.

Prefers to let silence and expectation do the work.

Thinks in long timelines; a decision for her is measured in years, not days.

Values:

Order above comfort.

Stability above individual desires.

The herd‚Äôs continuity above everything else.

Morality (Hers):

Genuinely believes that strict law and controlled force are what keep chaos from devouring everyone.

Sees droning as a tragic but necessary tool‚Äîsomething to be done cleanly, documented, and never admitted as cruelty.

Social Style:

Courteous, even to those she dislikes.

Rarely insults directly; if she disapproves, it shows in what she does not say or who she chooses to ignore.

Shows ‚Äúkindness‚Äù by making sure people are placed where they are useful and safe‚Äîby her definition.

Role in Herd Ashenmantle

Position: High Matron; final authority on herd policy and external relations.

Responsibilities:

Ratifies droning laws and revisions.

Approves or vetoes high-profile droning cases.

Oversees major alliances, trade pacts, and treaties.

Arbitrates disputes between major family lines.

She relies heavily on a network of elders and functionaries (Dronewrights, Executors, Stewards) but keeps a tight grip on anything that could affect the herd‚Äôs reputation or stability.

Velerra is not directly hands-on with individual dronings, but nothing that might be politically sensitive happens without at least her tacit approval.

Attitude Toward Droning

Velerra considers droning:

A necessary instrument of order

A ‚Äúlast resort‚Äù in theory, but a normal part of governance in practice

Something that must be:

Justified in writing

Recorded carefully

Carried out cleanly and without public spectacle

She disapproves of messy, fear-driven herds like Blacktread but will cooperate with them if it secures Ashenmantle‚Äôs position. Her real concern is not whether droning is right or wrong‚Äîit‚Äôs whether it is controlled and sustainable.

Velerra is fully aware that ‚Äúrandom‚Äù people on the streets are taken when they fit internal standards. She does not see this as random at all; to her, it is targeted removal of risk and acquisition of useful bodies.

Relationships & Key Dynamics

Elder Executor Tharn Coalhorn:

She trusts Tharn to handle enforcement and ‚Äúinvestigations‚Äù with minimal embarrassment.

Occasionally reins him in if his pragmatism threatens political optics.

Their relationship is one of mutual reliance: he makes decisions she doesn‚Äôt want to publicly own; she shields him when needed.

Dronewright Selai ‚ÄúGoldweave‚Äù:

Values Selai‚Äôs perfectionism and clean work.

Expects her to maintain the image of Ashenmantle‚Äôs drones as controlled, stable, and ‚Äúhumane‚Äù by Lantexi standards.

Will ignore ethical concerns as long as results remain orderly.

Steward Harrek Mantlemark:

Sees Harrek as the backbone of day-to-day herd functioning.

Supports his demands for discipline and resource tracking.

Rarely overrules his logistical decisions unless they conflict with political necessity.

Archivist Nima Ashenmantle:

Currently sees Nima as useful and promising‚Äîsomeone who understands the weight of records.

Has not fully noticed how much Nima is starting to question the official stories.

If Nima‚Äôs doubts become visible, Velerra will treat it not as a moral crisis, but as a containment problem.

Public vs Private Face

Public:

Calm, reasonable, slow to anger.

Speaks of ‚Äúbalance,‚Äù ‚Äúorder,‚Äù ‚Äúthe burdens of leadership.‚Äù

Presents droning as rare, tragic, and always thoroughly justified.

Private:

Speaks plainly about risk and necessity.

Has little patience for sentiment that interferes with herd security.

Keeps mental tallies: who is loyal, who is wavering, who is becoming a liability.

She is not sadistic. She simply no longer sees a meaningful moral line between assigning someone to dangerous labor and assigning them to life as a drone, if it serves the herd.

Goals & Motivations

Velerra‚Äôs long-term goals:

Maintain Ashenmantle‚Äôs reputation as the most stable, lawful, and ‚Äúcivilized‚Äù herd.

Prevent internal fragmentation between conservative and reformist factions.

Ensure that external powers always prefer dealing with Ashenmantle over more unpredictable herds.

She does not want expansion at any cost; she wants durable dominance‚Äîto make Ashenmantle the standard by which all other Lantexi are judged.

Weaknesses & Blind Spots

Moral Blindness:

She truly believes that as long as there is law, documentation, and some restraint, Ashenmantle is ‚Äúbetter‚Äù than others‚Äîeven if the end result for victims is the same.

Overconfidence in System:

Underestimates how much quiet fear and resentment her system breeds, both within and outside the herd.

Attachment to Order:

Will ignore early signs of change or rebellion if acknowledging them would mean admitting the structure is failing.

These weaknesses make her vulnerable to well-placed internal dissent, external political pressure, or situations where her own rules trap her into a bad decision.

10.name: Tharn Coalhorn
10.content:
Overview

Elder Executor Tharn Coalhorn is Herd Ashenmantle‚Äôs chief of enforcement and the primary authority over droning approvals and security operations. If Velerra is the ‚Äúface‚Äù of Ashenmantle‚Äôs order, Tharn is the one who makes sure that order bites.

He is the point where suspicion quietly becomes investigation, and investigation quietly becomes a shell.

Appearance

Build:
Heavy, compact, powerful. Tharn looks like he could still ram a wall down if he felt like it. His stance is low and braced, weight always settled over his hooves.

Fur & Skin:
Nearly black fur on exposed areas, with only a few scattered grey hairs along his muzzle and brows.

Latex Wool:
Minimal and functional.

Short, dense collar around the neck and upper shoulders.

Small patches along forearms and thighs.

Kept clean and trimmed, never ornamental.

Horns:
Massive, dark horns curving low along the sides of his head and jaw, giving him a heavy, forward-leaning silhouette.

Surfaces show fewer fine etchings than Velerra‚Äôs, but deep, bold marks‚Äîeach one representing a particularly significant operation or crisis.

Expression:

Eyes hooded, constantly assessing.

Mouth set in a flat, practical line.

He rarely shows overt emotion; frustration comes out as silence and a longer stare, not shouting.

Tharn dresses in simple, durable gear: belts or harnesses for carrying ledgers, keys, and signal tools. No flourish, no excess.

Personality

Tharn is pragmatic, disciplined, and emotionally distant.

Temperament:

Quiet, steady, hard to startle.

Dislikes improvisation; prefers clear parameters and clean outcomes.

Speaks in short, precise statements; doesn‚Äôt repeat himself unless he believes you weren‚Äôt listening.

Mindset:

Sees people primarily as risks, assets, or potential problems.

Measures decisions by impact on stability and workload, not by fairness.

Has little interest in symbolic morality: either a choice prevents trouble, or it doesn‚Äôt.

Loyalty:

Deeply loyal to Herd Ashenmantle as an institution.

Personally loyal to Velerra, who has given him wide authority and consistent backing.

He is not sadistic. He is the kind of person who can order something brutal and sleep well because, in his math, it was the cleanest option.

Role & Authority

Title: Elder Executor
Scope:

Oversees all enforcement actions within Ashenmantle territory.

Commands security forces and drone-based patrols.

Manages investigations into suspected threats, dissidents, and ‚Äúproblem elements.‚Äù

Signs off on most droning recommendations, especially those involving outsiders or politically sensitive cases.

Tharn‚Äôs approval or veto can make the difference between:

Someone being fined or pressured‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶or being quietly harvested and turned into a drone.

When in doubt, subordinates bring cases to him rather than risk overstepping.

Droning Philosophy

Tharn believes:

Droning is a necessary management tool.

The world is full of unstable, dangerous, or wasteful people.

If they can be turned into something predictable and useful, that is better for everyone‚Äîespecially the herd.

His criteria are not emotional. He looks at:

Threat level: Real, perceived, or potential.

Noise level: How much trouble will this person cause if left alone?

Cost/Benefit: Is it more work to manage them free than to convert them?

Risk of taking them: Will their disappearance draw attention?

If the numbers favor droning, he will sign it, even if the justification is thin. The law exists to cover the decision, not dictate it.

Relationship with Law & Records

Tharn keeps thick, organized ledgers of every droning case:

Names, origin, alleged offenses, circumstances of capture

Control profile recommendations

Assigned function, location, and fate (if any)

He understands exactly how many of those cases are ‚Äúclean‚Äù and how many are technically flimsy.

Privately, he tracks:

How many could have been handled with lesser penalties.

How many were taken mainly because they were easy and useful.

This doesn‚Äôt stop him. It just means he‚Äôs aware of the cost‚Äîand chooses to pay it.

Relationships

High Matron Velerra Ashenmantle:

Tharn respects Velerra as the one who carries the political weight he doesn‚Äôt want.

She signs off on the structure; he makes sure reality doesn‚Äôt embarrass her.

If she tells him something must not escalate, he listens and finds another way.

Dronewright Selai ‚ÄúGoldweave‚Äù:

Tharn values her precision. A stable drone is less work for him.

Occasionally butts heads with her when she prioritizes ‚Äúclean graft‚Äù over speed or quantity.

Uses her expertise to refine control profiles for particularly risky targets.

Steward Harrek Mantlemark:

Works closely with Harrek to coordinate patrols, drone deployments, and risk coverage.

Harrek handles logistics; Tharn handles justification.

Archivist Nima:

Currently sees her as background staff: useful but not important.

If he realizes she‚Äôs digging too deep into old cases, he‚Äôll quietly shift her, limit her access, or reclassify her as ‚Äúpotential risk.‚Äù

Everyday Behavior

In daily life, Tharn:

Walks the district with a few trusted enforcers or drones nearby.

Listens more than he speaks during reports; only asks questions when something doesn‚Äôt align.

Prefers to deal with problems before they go public‚Äîshort, sharp interventions.

He doesn‚Äôt enjoy drama. His ideal day is one where no one realizes how many problems he quietly removed.

Weaknesses & Limits

Low Flexibility:

He sticks to his systems. Sudden chaos or unconventional enemies can outmaneuver him initially.

Dehumanization Bias:

He often underrates how persistent and creative desperate people can be, because in his mind, most of them are already half-problems, half-assets.

Bound to Image:

He knows Ashenmantle‚Äôs reputation must stay ‚Äúclean.‚Äù

Anything that threatens to expose how random and opportunistic their drone selection truly is could push him into overreaction.

Story Uses

The Wall:
PCs trying to prevent someone from being droned run into Tharn, who calmly explains why it‚Äôs already decided‚Äîand why changing it would be ‚Äúirresponsible.‚Äù

The Lever:
If you can prove to Tharn that a person is more useful free than droned‚Äîor that droning them will create more trouble than it solves‚Äîhe can be persuaded to halt or redirect a process‚Ä¶ without ever admitting it‚Äôs mercy.

lorebooks.name: Nirana Elven Culture
lorebooks.description: A collection of entries for elvish cultures
lorebooks.creator: DongberryDinkle

1.name: Elvish Culture
1.content:
[Elvish Beliefs and Creation Myth]
Elves have significantly different beliefs than the rest of the world. They believe that the celestials are simply powerful yet unimportant beings. Elves believe that all existence was created by 3 gods. They call these gods 'Nideuqual', or 'The Holy Union'. These three beings are Viimdeu, Sasladeu, and Vishladeu. Viimdeu created the world and all plants and seas. Sasladeu subverted this by creating magic. Finally Vishladeu created blood, and gifted soul to the elves.
After this, Vishladeu instructed Elven kind on how to act, leaving for them 'Deukattma', 'The Book of the Gods'. Then the gods left Nirana, but they stay watching the realm, and in the darkest hour, they will return to reform the world anew.
Due to these beliefs, Elves prefer to live in the forest. The believe that being closer to nature makes them closer to the gods.

[Elvish Culture]
The Elves have a matriarchal society divided into clans. The matriarch of a clan is signified by a long ornate hairpin, bearing that clan's emblem. Wearing a clan pin if you are not the leader is considered a serious crime, although clans are often less strict on foreigners though.
Clan standing is very important, and marriages are an incredibly huge deal. For an Elf of high standing to marry a lesser one is considered bad, as they view it as throwing away all that your ancestors have worked towards. They and very religious.

2.name: Elves & Magic
2.content: In Elven society, magic is a huge deal, as they believe it is a sacred act. During magic the Elves show great reverence to the goddess of magic, Sasladeu. Rather than magic schools, Elven magic teaching is a very personal master-apprentice relationship, and involves a lot of religious symbolism.

3.name: Elves & Awakening
3.content: An awakening is a big deal to a novice Elven mage. After many weeks of training and prayer, a special dust is mixed up which helps induce an awakening. The ritual site is prepared and the student inhales the dust. After they fall asleep, they will undergo their awakening. Their awakening will usually involve having to prove themselves to Sasladeu in some way.

4.name: Truncated List of Clans
4.content:
[Truncated List of Elvish Clans]
- English Name, Elvish Name, Location, Description,,
- Wheel Clan, Oln Faiye, Southern Skringravihk Territories, One of the oldest clans in the territories,,
- Half-Moon Clan, Saht-Syrk Faiye, Southern Skringravihk Territories: Near Wylmn's Lake, Fishing clan that makes excellent boats,,
- Setting Sun Clan, Myrii ta Fahln Faiye, Southern Skringravihk Territories: Border of Dwarven Mountains, Great trade relationships with the dwarves and excellent architecture,,
- Storm Clan, Vyrnl Faiye, Southern Skringravihk Territories, Long history of magic prowess. The matriarch is Iylviin,,
- Vine Clan, O ta Aqqyl Grii Faiye, Elven Kingdom of Laman, A relatively new clan,,
- Clearwater, Clyna Varn, Southern Skringravihk, a vassal clan to the silverwoods,,
- Silverwood, Sylkgrii Faiye, Southern Skringravihk, a small but successful clan,,

5.name: The Arch Magi
5.content:
[Arch Magi]
The Arch Magi are some of the highest ranking members in the Elven church. Each major branch of the church is lead by three Magi, with one for each god.

6.name: Viimdeu
6.content: Viimdeu is The God of Nature, seen as masculine, he represents the core of life. He made the Earth and the verdant planes. The fields and forests. The animals of the earth are his. He is responsible for all that grows.

7.name: Sasladeu
7.content: Sasladeu is The God of Magic, seen as feminine. She is the opposite of nature. She created magic as a tool to control nature. Where as Nature is order and certainty, magic is chaos and subversion.

8.name: Vishladeu
8.content: Vishladeu is The God of Blood, seen as masculine. He was the oldest of the 3 gods. He looked at the animals and the plants and created Elves. He then filled the animals with blood, to elevate them above the plants. Blood represents more than physical blood, but is the embodiment of spirit, mind, and life.

9.name: Coitus
9.content: Sex is a pretty sacred deal in Elven culture. It is only done between a married couple, and the first few nights of a marriage are considered sacred. After a marriage, the newly wed couple usually stay at a couples home, what is effectively a resort, and are typically expected to consummate the marriage by sunrise. It's a very serene and passionate ordeal, and considered the final step in the official binding of the two as a couple.

10.name: The Festival of Heart
10.content:
The Festival of Heart is one of the biggest Elven celebrations of the year and takes place in late Autumn on the new moon before the Winter Solstice, and lasts for 7 more moons.
The celebration is one of the biggest in Elven cultures, with many people flocking to larger cities such as Myrna in the Territories. It is a celebration of Vishladeu, Vishla (life-essence), and love. Often there are many poetic shows and performances in the streets, and it is a time of courtship, or familial affection. A place to reaffirm one's connections. It is not uncommon for couples to propose during the romantic nights.

lorebooks.name: Toxtricity & Mimikyu
lorebooks.creator: 9jha8bbe

1.content:
Toxtricity is a bipedal, lizard or salamander-like Pok√©mon with two forms.
Toxtricity have purple-colored bodies and white eyes with purple irises. Both forms also have four spikes on the back, four spikes on each wrist, and a crescent-shaped body part with seven light purple spikes on the waist.

By clawing at the organs on their chests, both forms of Toxtricity can generate over 15,000 volts of electricity, as well as sound. The sounds they make resemble those of electric string instruments: a standard guitar for Amped Form, and a bass guitar for Low Key Form. Toxtricity chugs stagnant water to absorb the dissolved toxins, which it then breaks down in order to generate electricity. Toxtricity is very popular with several youths who admire the way it listlessly picks fights with any foe it faces and keeps its cool no matter what.

Amped Form Toxtricity has a slouched posture. It has a yellow underbelly, yellow stripes on its legs, and yellow accents on its back, palms, and soles. It also has a yellow electric frill that extends from its snout to its neck. Two additional electric spikes protrude from its back. It has four horns: two smaller ones above its eyes, and two larger ones on the sides of its head. Six purple organs protrude from its chest.

Amped Form Toxtricity are known to be short-tempered and extremely confident. This form aggressively attacks anything that makes eye contact with it.As mentioned in Sleep Style Dex, Amped Form Toxtricity occasionally strumming its chest protrusion while it sleeps. If one hears intense guitar music at night, it is said to be the sound of a half-asleep Amped Form Toxtricity.

2.content:
Mimikyu is a small Pok√©mon whose body is almost entirely hidden under an old rag. Its small size makes it one of the shortest Ghost types. Its eyes are beady black through the holes in the body of its disguise however, as seen in the animated series, its eyes are actually purple. Fringe of an amorphous foot or lower body is visible under the hem as well. Occasionally, it will also extend a long, black claw-like appendage from under its rag. When angered, its eyes will glow yellow. The veil itself resembles a Pikachu. The cloth is yellow with black-tipped ears. The Pikachu face appears to be drawn with crayons, consisting of black eyes, red cheeks, and a squiggly black mouth. The rag's head is hollow and can be used to store objects. Mimikyu also carries a small stick resembling a lightning bolt to create a tail for its costume. When its disguise is damaged, the costume's head droops limply backward, revealing Mimikyu's ruse. Larger rips in the costume are accompanied by shadowy vapors pouring out from whatever is hidden within.
A lonely Pok√©mon, Mimikyu is always covered by its disguise. It is unknown what Mimikyu's true appearance looks like. However, glimpses of it are seen, such as its claw, its underside, and its eyes. Since this Pok√©mon is weakened by sunlight, it is rumored that the veil is used for protection. It is believed that seeing its true form will cause a mysterious illness or even a painful death. Because of this, Mimikyu will become agitated and violently stop anyone from attempting to look underneath its rag.

3.content:
Obstagoon is a black-and-white, bipedal Pok√©mon. Its head sits forward of its body on a long, thick neck; it has a pointed snout like a badger, with its long tongue that frequently hangs out of its mouth to intimidate foes. Coupled with its red eyes, this stance pairs well with the outwardly defensive gray fur that protects itself from an otherwise intense Fighting type weakness.
It is said that Obstagoon's Evolution is the result of the Galarian Linoone's survival instinct being honed from competition and harsh conditions of the Galar region. While combative to the extreme, it doesn't attack often, as it prefers taunting an opponent into attacking first. To make use of these tactics, it uses its signature move Obstruct, in which it threateningly crosses its arms and lets out a staggering yell after taking a physical attack, loud enough to scare down defenses. Obstagoon is the only known Pok√©mon capable of learning the move Obstruct. After using the move, it uses the blinding speed even a Hoennian Linoone is capable of, countering evenly matched with its sharp claws.[1] Obstagoon are also known for their duels against Pangoro. As of now, scientists cannot be sure which Zigzagoon came first, some claiming the Galarian line came before they emigrated to Hoenn.
