1.name: Totem Pok√©mon
1.content:
Totem Pok√©mon (Japanese: „Å¨„Åó„Éù„Ç±„É¢„É≥ Leader Pok√©mon) are a select group of wild Pok√©mon that are battled at the end of every trial. Most Totem Pok√©mon have been trained by their respective Trial Captain, who also provided them their role. Trainers who beat these Pok√©mon and by extension, complete the trial, are rewarded with a Z-Crystal.
Totem Pok√©mon cannot be caught under normal circumstances, however, in exchange for Totem Stickers, Totem-like Pok√©mon can be obtained from Samson Oak at Heahea Beach.
In the core series games
Pok√©mon Sun, Moon, Ultra Sun, and Ultra Moon
At the start of a battle, Totem Pok√©mon are enveloped in a special Z-Power aura that boosts one or more of its stats by a fixed number of stages. According to Wicke, this aura is a result of being bathed in the energy spilled by Ultra Wormholes, which is the same kind the Ultra Beasts happen to store in their bodies as they pass through a wormhole. In Pok√©mon Ultra Sun and Ultra Moon, this energy is revealed to be Necrozma's light.[3] While their height is only visual aesthetic, their weight mechanically affect moves such as Grass Knot, Heavy Slam, and Sky Drop.
Totem Pok√©mon are battled in SOS Battles, which allows them to summon an ally to help. SOS Battles with Totem Pok√©mon differ from regular SOS Battles in that their supply of allies may be limited, which allies they call is not influenced by the weather, and they call allies at specific times rather than at random (as such, their calls are unaffected by Adrenaline Orbs or status conditions). Both the Totem Pok√©mon and their allies have more advanced artificial intelligence than wild Pok√©mon, mirroring Trainer behavior. Totem Pok√©mon each also hold a specific item, usually one that will synergize effectively with their particular strategies or cover their weaknesses. Due to the island challenge rules, Totem Pok√©mon and their allies cannot be caught. Like all wild Pok√©mon, if the player steals an item from a Totem Pok√©mon (e.g., via Thief), the player's Pok√©mon will still be holding the stolen item at the end of battle.
The battle theme for the Totem Pok√©mon is a remix of the wild Pok√©mon battle theme from the original Pok√©mon Sun and Moon. Totem Pok√©mon and Totem-like Pok√©mon are not registered in the Pok√©dex as unique forms, despite behaving as such.

2.name: Noble Pok√©mon
2.content:
The noble Pok√©mon (Japanese: „Ç≠„É≥„Ç∞„Éª„ÇØ„Ç§„Éº„É≥ Kings and Queens) are a select group of Pok√©mon that are dedicated to watch over and protect the humans and Pok√©mon of Hisui, where they're worshiped by the Diamond and Pearl Clans. They're descendants of five of the ten companions of the ancient hero of legend. The descendants of the other five are the ride Pok√©mon.
Background
Thousands of years prior to Pok√©mon Legends: Arceus, the ancient hero and his ten Pok√©mon companions reached and defeated the being known as almighty Sinnoh, receiving its blessing as a sign of its respect. Their descendants would then inherit both their blessing and the duty of protecting the Hisui region and its inhabitants. There are a total of five noble Pok√©mon who, along with the five ride Pok√©mon, are each overseen by a warden of the Diamond or Pearl Clan. These Pok√©mon are often larger than their standard counterparts and cannot be caught.
Pok√©mon Legends: Arceus
Due to the space-time rift created by Giratina atop Mount Coronet, the four noble Pok√©mon became frenzied. Later on, after Growlithe evolved into the noble Arcanine during the player's research at the Cobalt Coastlands, it became frenzied as well. To quell a noble Pok√©mon, the player must throw balms made of the noble's favorite food until its frenzy gauge reaches zero. After being quelled, each noble Pok√©mon will grant the player the plate corresponding to its primary type.
In the post-game, the player can have a rematch against the nobles at their respective arenas by talking to the warden. The challenges will be identical, except the noble Pok√©mon will all be at Lv. 70 with full effort levels, and the player is timed for personal records.
Statues of all noble and ride Pok√©mon, built by the Celestica people, can be found at the Temple of Sinnoh. However, these statues are destroyed by Dialga/Palkia when it changed into its Origin Forme.
It's unknown what happened to the Noble Pok√©mon in the present day of Sinnoh.

3.name: Titan Pok√©mon
3.content:
Titan Pok√©mon (Japanese: „Éå„Ç∑„Éù„Ç±„É¢„É≥ Leader Pok√©mon) are a type of variant Pok√©mon encountered in the "Path of Legends" storyline of Pok√©mon Scarlet and Violet. They appear much larger than other Pok√©mon of their kind, and are guardians of the Herba Mystica, rare ingredients said to be able to restore health instantly when eaten.
Background
200 years prior to the events of Pok√©mon Scarlet and Violet, the Area Zero exploration team, led by Heath, discovered the Herba Mystica hidden deep within Area Zero, in the Great Crater of Paldea, located in the center of the region. They recorded information on the herbs in the Scarlet BookS/Violet BookV and gave the Herba Mystica their proper name. They subsequently discovered that the Herba Mystica comes in five different flavor varieties with separate healing effects, and may also cause Pok√©mon to grow huge. Due to the first discovery, the team attempted to grow the herbs outside of Area Zero, in different sites around Paldea, but before they were able to harvest them, the herbs were eaten by Pok√©mon, leading to the first appearances of Titan Pok√©mon on the surface. As a result, the project was abandoned.
At some point, a Paradox Pok√©mon called Great TuskS/Iron TreadsV somehow escaped Area Zero and consumed the Herba Mystica, and therefore became the Quaking Earth Titan.
In Naranja AcademyS/Uva AcademyV's library, copies of the Scarlet BookS/Violet BookV can be found with a page detailing the effects of Herba Mystica on Pok√©mon, such as healing (as seen with an Eevee) and growing (as seen with a Gible).
Pok√©mon Scarlet and Violet
Path of Legends
Titan Pok√©mon are ordinary Pok√©mon empowered and grown to gigantic proportions by the Herba Mystica they eat. There are a total of five Titan Pok√©mon fights to accomplish. Each Titan Pok√©mon is fought twice; the first fight is done alone, while the second fight is done together with Arven. After defeating a Titan Pok√©mon as part of the story, it can be encountered again in the same area it was fought as a normal-sized Pok√©mon (albeit one that is the largest possible size for their species), where it can be caught. These Pok√©mon will have the Titan Mark, which allows them to be given the title "the Former Titan"; they are also guaranteed to have an IV of 30 for all stats.
The Teal Mask
A similar battle state known as Titanic is achieved by the Loyal Three after being resurrected, implied to be caused by the villagers of Mossui Town feeding them Kitakami Mochi made with special herbs.

4.name: Brilliant Pok√©mon
4.content:
Brilliant Pok√©mon (Japanese: „Ç™„Éº„É©„Éù„Ç±„É¢„É≥ Aura Pok√©mon) are Pok√©mon with special auras in the overworld that can appear in Pok√©mon Sword and Shield. They have certain properties that are distinct from other Pok√©mon in the area.
Brilliant Pok√©mon can be encountered by one of two methods: as symbol encounters or via fishing. Symbol encounter Brilliant Pok√©mon give off a visible yellow aura in the overworld, whereas when fishing the aura is around the fishing spot. Once the player encounters the Pok√©mon, its aura is not seen again.
Properties
Brilliant Pok√©mon have the following properties:
They are the highest possible level for their Encounter Slot.
They know an Egg Move.
They have two or three of their IVs guaranteed to be 31.
The player earns Watts for catching or defeating them, with high-level Brilliant Pok√©mon yielding more Watts.
They receive additional bonus rolls for being Shiny, up to a total of 6 rerolls at 500 caught/defeated.

5.name: Alpha Pok√©mon
5.content:
An alpha Pok√©mon (Japanese: „Ç™„É§„Éñ„É≥ boss) is a variety of Pok√©mon that were introduced in Pok√©mon Legends: Arceus. They are larger-than-normal Pok√©mon that appear in the wild with increased combat capabilities. Alpha Pok√©mon can be identified with the  icon in the Pok√©mon's summary screen and on their health bar in the wild (if transferred to Pok√©mon Scarlet and Violet, they have the Alpha Mark instead). Additionally, wild alpha Pok√©mon have glowing red eyes, with the exception of Zubat; this trait is not retained upon capture.
In Pok√©mon Scarlet and Violet, Pok√©mon who were previously identified as alpha Pok√©mon will have the title "Former Alpha" and with the Alpha Mark  instead.
Alpha Pok√©mon returned in Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A, retaining the same traits and behavior as in Legends: Arceus.
In the core series games
Pok√©mon Legends: Arceus
Shortly after the player joins the Survey Corps, an alpha Kricketune intrudes Deertrack Heights. Mai, the warden who oversees Wyrdeer, enlists Akari/Rei to help defeat the Kricketune, who in turn asks the player to aid Mai due to their skill in Pok√©mon battles.
While Ingo is leading the player through Wayward Cave, an alpha Crobat appears along the route. Ingo insists that the player not battle it due to the reduced visibility caused by the absence of the cave's torches, and leads them on a detour to avoid it. The player is unable to battle or catch this particular alpha Pok√©mon until Ingo reinstalls the torches in the cave.
During the three Trials of the Lake guardians, the player has to face an alpha Pok√©mon at each lake; Hisuian Goodra at Lake Verity, Overqwil at Lake Valor, and Hisuian Zoroark at Lake Acuity.
During the post-game, when the player goes to meet Volo at Grueling Grove, the two are ambushed by an alpha Vespiquen. After defeating the Pok√©mon, the player receives a Stone Plate from it.
Gameplay
In the wild, alpha Pok√©mon will be at a higher level than other species of the same kind that can be found in that area, will have at least three stats with individual values of 31 (expressed in this game as initial effort levels of 3) and will know and have mastered a move that cannot be learned by leveling up, selected at random from among the species' list of Move Tutor moves. Alpha Pok√©mon cannot be caught outside of battle if they are significantly higher level than the player's current obedience level. They can, however, be caught regardless of level during a battle with them. If caught, alpha Pok√©mon will count as heavy specimens and large specimens for research tasks. Regardless of the species' normal behavior, alpha Pok√©mon (except for Mantyke and Mantine) are always aggressive towards the player and will never run away, unless a space-time distortion appears around it or it is a species which only appears in the wild at certain times of day. If an alpha Pok√©mon spots the player, it will roar out a shockwave which, if close enough, will cause the player to be knocked to the ground; they are also forcibly dismounted from their Ride Pok√©mon if riding Wyrdeer, Ursaluna, or Sneasler.
Upon entering battle, wild alpha Pok√©mon are filled with Wild Might (Japanese: ÈáéÊÄß„ÅÆÂäõ Wild Strength), as indicated by their glowing red eyes. This increases all of a Pok√©mon's stats, independently of in-battle stat boosts, and reduces damage from status conditions. Alpha Pok√©mon can also use agile style and strong style moves in battle.
There are three types of ways alpha Pok√©mon may spawn:
Fixed alpha Pok√©mon spawns will always be generated upon entering a given area of the Hisui region, and will be at a fixed level; for instance, the alpha Rapidash in the Obsidian Fieldlands is always Lv. 40. These alpha Pok√©mon will also automatically respawn after two full in-game days.
Random alpha Pok√©mon spawns may occur after the player has quelled the area's noble Pok√©mon. Alpha Pok√©mon, of the same species as the location's standard spawns, each have a small chance of appearing (between a 0.2% and 2% chance). Each location has its own rates for how likely each alpha Pok√©mon may spawn, including space-time distortions. Prior to the Daybreak update, during mass outbreaks, at most one alpha Pok√©mon could appear, however this limit was later lifted to account for the "exclusively alpha" bonus waves of massive mass outbreaks.
During a massive mass outbreak, clearing all Pok√©mon in a location may cause a second wave of Pok√©mon to appear in the same location; if this occurs, the second wave may be composed entirely of alpha Pok√©mon.
During the battle against Giratina at the Temple of Sinnoh, it will be filled with Terrible Might (Japanese: „Åô„Åï„Åæ„Åò„ÅÑÂäõ Tremendous Strength), which has an identical effect to Wild Might.
In Pok√©mon Scarlet and Violet, alpha Pok√©mon transferred from Legends: Arceus will gain the Alpha Mark. They will not retain their unique sizes in these games, but will return to their alpha size when brought back to Legends: Arceus. Instead, they will be at the largest non-alpha height value that the species can have.
Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A
Like in Legends: Arceus, alpha Pok√©mon are larger than is typical of their species, have red glowing eyes, and will chase and attack the player. They are powerful and difficult to catch. Like in Legends: Arceus, Alpha Pokemon always have at least three random individual values at the maximum value of 31, and know and have mastered one move that their species doesn't normally learn by level up, but in Legends: Z-A, each species always gets the same mastered TM move every time it appears in the wild. Alpha Pokemon in Legends: Z-A also spawn with the maximum 252 effort values in HP already applied.
The real-time battle system gives the size of alpha Pok√©mon an impact on battles. Larger Pok√©mon are easier to hit, especially by indirect attacks in 4-player battles. They also can get stuck more easily. Ranged attacks coming from a certain part of the body may come out at less accurate angles. However, direct attacks can benefit from larger hitboxes.
Alpha Pok√©mon will start to appear throughout Lumiose City after completing Side Mission 1: "A Big Ol' Bunnelby".

6.name: Crystal Pok√©mon
6.content:
Crystal Pok√©mon (Japanese: „Éã„É•„Éº„Éà„É©„É´„Éù„Ç±„É¢„É≥ Neutral Pok√©mon) are a type of Pok√©mon in the Pok√©mon Trading Card Game. They are considered by fans to be the e-Series equivalent of the Shining Pok√©mon previously introduced in the later Neo expansions, Neo Revelation and Neo Destiny. However, the Pok√©mon featured in each of the cards are not alternately colored.
Introduced in Aquapolis, Crystal Pok√©mon are identified by being Colorless but focus on three particular types of Energy to use in its attacks. All Crystal Pok√©mon have the Pok√©-Body Crystal Type, in which the type of the Pok√©mon changes from Colorless to one of three specified types if the corresponding Energy card is placed on it, for one turn. These types are also emphasized on the card design; for example, Celebi's Pok√©-Body and attacks focus on Grass, Water and Psychic; the colors green, blue and purple are highlighted in the card background.
Crystal Pok√©mon are also not necessarily Basic Pok√©mon, and are counted as regular Pok√©mon. While they weren't bound by the one per deck rule like Shining Pok√©mon, they still featured several Energy for each attack and were quite costly for the effects they provided.
In Japan, these cards were released three at a time over the course of the last three e-Card expansions, but with the hurried release of the English sets and their condensation, Skyridge featured six. In both languages, all Crystal Pok√©mon are secret cards. Crystal Pok√©mon were retired at the end of the e-Card Series.
Within the AI chat
There are no Crystal Pok√©mon that have Normal as their original type. All Pok√©mon other than Normal-type Pok√©mon have the potential to become Crystal Pok√©mon.
The Crystal Pok√©mon's type becomes Normal, and its Ability becomes Normal Skin.
Crystal Pok√©mon are rare Pok√©mon.

7.name: Dark Pok√©mon
7.content:
Dark Pok√©mon (Japanese: „Çè„Çã„ÅÑ„Éù„Ç±„É¢„É≥ Bad Pok√©mon) are a variant of Pok√©mon found in the Pok√©mon Trading Card Game. They are considered a corrupted version of their normal species, and the result of having been raised improperly. They are the counterpart of Light Pok√©mon.
Introduced in the Team Rocket expansion, Dark Pok√©mon are associated with the Team Rocket organization. They are said to have evolved differently due to Team Rocket raising their unevolved forms without proper love and attention. Gym Heroes touched on the theme with the introduction of Rocket's Pok√©mon, similar in many respects to Dark Pok√©mon from the previous expansion. While Dark Pok√©mon are nearly always evolved Pok√©mon, Rocket's Pok√©mon are instead nearly always Basic Pok√©mon. They tend to have higher attack damage and lower HP values compared to those of normal Pok√©mon, likely due to the highly offensive nature of their Trainer. As the word "Dark" is part of the card's name, one can include up to 4 of each the regular and Dark versions of the same species in the same deck.
Dark Pok√©mon reappeared in the Neo Destiny expansion, which as the title suggests, revolves around the potential path or "destiny" a Pok√©mon can follow depending on how it is brought up by its Trainer. The expansion showcased the difference between Pok√©mon with Dark in their names and Darkness-type Pok√©mon, with Dark Houndoom and Dark Tyranitar released as Fire-type and Fighting-type Pok√©mon, respectively.
Though Dark Pok√©mon did not appear in the EX Team Magma vs Team Aqua expansion, Pok√©mon belonging to Team Aqua or Team Magma utilized the new game mechanic of dual-types, in which many Pok√©mon acquired a Darkness dual type to further emphasize their allegiance to a villainous team. Dark Pok√©mon would properly return in the EX Hidden Legends and EX Team Rocket Returns expansions. In line with the precedent set by Team Magma's and Team Aqua's Pok√©mon, all Dark Pok√©mon in the EX Series are dual Darkness-type, with the exception of those that are normally Colorless. This essentially rejected the difference between Dark Pok√©mon and Darkness-type Pok√©mon displayed in Neo Destiny. Unlike their earlier counterparts, HP and damage values on Dark Pok√©mon in the EX Series are roughly in line with other cards from the era. Dark Celebi from EX Hidden Legends is notably the only Dark Pok√©mon that is an unevolved species; however, this card is instead printed as a Rocket's Pok√©mon in Japan.
After a long absence of the mechanic, Dark SylveonVwas printed as one of the SWSH Black Star Promos to celebrate the Pok√©mon 25th Anniversary.
Aesthetically, the artwork on Dark Pok√©mon cards feature dark colors and harsh shadows. In the Original and Neo Series, Dark Pok√©mon have a brown and black artwork window, Evolution box, and Pok√©dex box, as opposed to the regular gold. Also, most Generation I Pok√©mon feature Ken Sugimori's Pok√©mon Red and Blue artwork of their previous Stage in the Evolution box, instead of the usual Pok√©mon Red and Green artwork. In EX Team Rocket Returns, the dual-type template on Dark Pok√©mon is modified to emphasize the Darkness type, rather than having an even split of both types as seen on other dual-type cards.
Within the AI chat
All Pok√©mon owned by villainous teams such as Team Rocket, Team Aqua, Team Magma, Team Galactic, Team Plasma, Team Flare, Team Skull, Team Yell, and Team Star become Dark Pok√©mon.

8.name: Light Pok√©mon
8.content:
Light Pok√©mon (Japanese: „ÇÑ„Åï„Åó„ÅÑ„Éù„Ç±„É¢„É≥ Gentle Pok√©mon) are a variant of Pok√©mon found in the Pok√©mon Trading Card Game. They are the counterpart of Dark Pok√©mon.
Light Pok√©mon were introduced in the 2001 Neo Destiny expansion, which as the title suggests, revolves around the potential path or "destiny" a Pok√©mon can follow depending on how it is brought up by their Trainer. Similar to their Dark Pok√©mon counterparts, Light Pok√©mon are always evolved Pok√©mon. They tend to have slightly higher HP values compared to those of normal Pok√©mon, and their attacks often provide support effects that can aid either player. As the word "Light" is part of the card's name, one can include up to 4 of each the regular and Light versions of the same species in the same deck.
Although Dark Pok√©mon returned in the 2004 EX Series, Light Pok√©mon remained absent from the TCG until 2021, when Light Toxtricity was printed as one of the 2019-2023 SWSH Black Star Promos for the Pok√©mon 25th Anniversary.
Aesthetically, the artwork on Light Pok√©mon cards feature bright highlights and depict serene environments. They also have a white and gold artwork window, Evolution box and Pok√©dex box, as opposed to the regular gold.

9.name: Radiant Pok√©mon
9.content:
Radiant Pok√©mon (Japanese: „Åã„Åå„ÇÑ„Åè„Éù„Ç±„É¢„É≥ Sparkling Pok√©mon) are a subgroup of Shiny Pok√©mon.[1] They are depicted as a group of Pok√©mon cards in the Pok√©mon Trading Card Game, and were introduced in the Astral Radiance expansion. Radiant Pok√©mon cards feature an exclusive foiling style. These Pok√©mon have powerful attacks and Abilities. All Radiant Pok√©mon are Basic Pok√©mon regardless of if the species is an Evolution of a different species. Their names use "Radiant" as a prefix. For example, a Radiant Pok√©mon card depicting Charjabug is named "Radiant Charjabug".
Radiant Pok√©mon have the Radiant Pok√©mon rule, printed in a Rule Box below their artwork. It says that players cannot have more than one Radiant Pok√©mon card in their deck. However, the "Radiant" naming is part of the card's name, so one player can have, for example, 4 Gardevoir cards and 1 Radiant Gardevoir card in the same deck.
Radiant Pok√©mon do not have Pok√©dex information printed on their cards, precluding their use in the occasional card that that needs data such as their height.

10.name: Œ¥ Delta Species
10.content:
Œ¥ Delta Species (Japanese: Œ¥-„Éá„É´„ÇøÁ®Æ Œ¥-Delta Species) are a type of Pok√©mon found in the Pok√©mon Trading Card Game. The term is often shortened to Œ¥, DS, Delta, or Delta Species. They first appeared in the EX Delta Species expansion, and were last released in the EX Dragon Frontiers expansion.
Œ¥ Delta Species are different from normal Pok√©mon in that their type is not the expected type for a Pok√©mon of their species; however, they still have the same Weaknesses that a regular Pok√©mon of their species would have. For example, Charmander Œ¥ is a Lightning-type Pok√©mon, as opposed to a Fire-type but still has a Weakness to the Water-type rather than gaining a Weakness to the Fighting-type.
According to the backstory offered in EX Delta Species, Pok√©mon in Holon became Œ¥ Delta Species upon exposure to the electromagnetic waves emitted by the Holon Research Tower. The scientists that discovered them used the Greek letter Œ¥, as Œ¥ Delta Species are the fourth discovered classification of Pok√©mon after normal Pok√©mon, Pok√©mon-ex, and Pok√©mon ‚òÜ.
Dual type Pok√©mon Œ¥ always have Metal as their secondary type, and it is nearly always fully evolved Pok√©mon or Legendary Pok√©mon that display this. However, with the release of EX Dragon Frontiers, no Pok√©mon Œ¥ displayed this Metal dual type, leading some to believe that these Pok√©mon became Œ¥ Delta Species naturally or the trait was outbred on the island habitats in which they live. Appearance-wise, Œ¥ Delta Species Pok√©mon do not differ from normal Pok√©mon other than an aura that denotes its type; some have a more distinct aura than others.
In EX Delta Species, if a Œ¥ Delta Species Pok√©mon had one of its types changed to something other than Metal, it was always either to Fire or Lightning. This is likely due to the fact that, since these two types are based upon one of the game types each, whereas others are based on more, all cards of those two types shared a single weakness among them: Water and Fighting, respectively. Thus, Fire Pok√©mon and Lightning Pok√©mon became more playable by diversifying their weaknesses. Later sets did not do this, however, and Delta Species Pok√©mon could be of any type.
Delta Species Pok√©mon have "Œ¥ Delta Species" between the name and HP, had double helix on the border of the artwork window, and the Evolution box featured a Œ¥ design.
The designation of Œ¥ Delta Species does not affect the name of a Pok√©mon (e.g. a normal Dragonite can evolve from a Dragonair Œ¥ and vice versa). If a card wishes to reference Œ¥ Delta Species, it uses the text "Pok√©mon that has Œ¥ on its card," even when the effect has multiple targets. The card Ampharos Œ¥ has the Pok√©-Body Holon Veil, which causes all of Pok√©mon cards of its owner to be treated as though they have Œ¥ on their card. This applies even while those cards are in the deck, hand, or discard pile. Holon Veil has been described as causing the affected Pok√©mon to become Delta Species, although Holon Veil does not have a type changing effe
Within the AI chat
It will only appear if {{user}} permits the appearance of Œ¥ Delta Species.
Pok√©mon of the Œ¥ Delta Species appear as Pok√©mon with a different primary type compared to Pok√©mon of the same species.
Œ¥ Delta Species are rare Pok√©mon. When a Œ¥ Delta Species Pok√©mon evolves and gains an additional type, its primary type remains unchanged.
